awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Smart Mouth Guard for Measurements of Physiology and Physical Effects
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to minimize short-and long- term effects of heat exhaustion and heat stroke, impact, and other conditions.  The proposed project advances an oral system capable of monitoring physiology and physical responses.  The initial application of athletics enables development of a tool that can be used more broadly for health monitoring of military forces and other users at risk.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop a durable, adaptable, and wholly instrumented physiology monitoring mouth guard system that can provide real-time tracking of a range of biometrics, such as impact force and body temperature. Intra-oral measurements lend themselves monitoring and assessment, and a mouth guard can collect precise multi-sensor data at low power, then transmit data wirelessly. The proposed research and development activities will focus on development and integration of sensors and wireless communication capabilities for real-time data on health (e.g., core temperature), movement (e.g., acceleration, rotational motion), and impact forces (e.g., high-velocity collision).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Teams at all levels of competition, from professional to amateur sports, and across a variety of sports, are actively seeking new ways to keep their players safe and to improve their level of performance. The sports community is looking at new technologies to lower injury risk during play and to increase youth participation in sports.

TWG's SMART mouthguard fills a gap in the market by assisting parents, trainers and medical personnel in identifying injured players at the earliest possible stage before suffering a catastrophic injury. TWG has invented a mouthguard capable of physiological status monitoring for amateur athletes, not only to prevent injuries and keep them healthy, but also to improve their on-field performance and gather useful data and insights. TWG's smart wireless physiological monitoring device is an instrumented mouthguard capable of recording and monitoring several biometrics simultaneously using MEMS (Micro-Electro-Mechanical-Systems) sensors embedded in the mouthguard. TWG's technology is unique in that it combines several sensors to monitor and record the athlete's temperature, linear accelerations, and angular rotations from the oral cavity in a single wearable device, as well as the capacity to broadcast that data in near-real-time.

TWGs device measures the force and direction of movement an athlete?s jaw and head experiences during an impact. This impact can be primary, such as a direct collision to the athlete?s head, or secondary: force imparted to the athlete?s head due to an impact elsewhere on their body. Some athletes are exposed to high impacts, so a high-G 3-axis accelerometer is implemented. There are expectations of lower force impacts with critical directivity, so a precision low-G 3-axis accelerometer is also implemented. The devices selected are low-power and have small footprints. The device also measures angular rotation values an athlete?s head and neck experiences during an impact. This impact can be primary, such as a direct collision to the athlete?s head, or secondary: such as force imparted to the athlete?s head due to an impact elsewhere on their body. A 3-axis gyroscope sensor is integrated within the same package as the precision accelerometer on coincident axes. This configuration can be used to measure the athlete?s normal ranges and rates of motion, which must be discernable and accommodated dynamically during performance. A low-powered precision temperature sensor is also integrated within the device which allows for recording of temperature readings to determine if the athlete?s body is within its normal range of performance during and after activities.

Our Phase I R&D work has led to an open architecture prototype platform that allows for connection of other devices on two different communication buses. In the future, TWG intends to add other biometric capabilities, such as pH, O2, glucose, and others, to the communications bus and software to improve the devices value proposition.

 


Last Modified: 05/26/2022
Modified by: Michael D Wright
